content:
Let M\mathcal MM be a monoidal category. Suppose I give an identity-on-objects monoidal functor B:M→MrevB : \mathcal M \to \mathcal M^{rev}B:M→Mrev, where 'rev' denotes the same monoidal category 'reversed' tensor (as we agreed on #learning: questions > reverse of a monoidal category?).
Let ϵ:I=I\epsilon : I = Iϵ:I=I be its unit constraint and βm,n:m⊗n→n⊗m\beta_{m,n} : m \otimes n \to n \otimes mβm,n​:m⊗n→n⊗m its monoidal constraint. The latter has all the looks of a braiding. Indeed, the unit axioms coincide perfectly, but then the axioms for β\betaβ are subtly yet fundamentally different: braidings.png
(The top one is one of the usual axioms of braiding, whereas the bottom one is the associativity axiom for β\betaβ)
It's evident that if β\betaβ is indeed a braiding, then it does satisfy the second axiom, i.e. associativity, by coherence. But the converse is not obvious, and probably simply not true.

We could call this structure a 'semibraiding': it's enough to swap things around, associatively, but it doesn't go all the way to a braiding.
So, first of all, is this notion sensible? Or am I missing some other 'obvious' requirement for β\betaβ that would make it a braiding?
Secondly, is this notion known?
Notice that one might as well drop the requirement that BBB is identity-on-objects, and contemplate lax monoidal functors M→Mrev\mathcal M \to \mathcal M^{rev}M→Mrev
I cannot answer any of the questions but I find it a very elegant and interesting way to define a braiding-like structure.

I just noticed that a 'semisymmetry', i.e. a semibraiding such that βm,n;βn,m=1m⊗n\beta_{m,n} ; \beta_{n,m} = 1_{m \otimes n}βm,n​;βn,m​=1m⊗n​, is the same thing as a symmetry! In fact if you swap the two leftmost wires on both sides of the associativity law (the second one in the diagrams in the op) you get the hexagon axiom.

I think it's interesting to think about this from the perspective of operads.

(Having written the following, I think it's a bit off, because I don't think an E2E_2E2​ algebra is necessarily an algebra for the operad (E1)C2(E_1)_{C_2}(E1​)C2​​ I describe below. So in the following definition, "braided" does not imply "semibraided"! I think I will post this anyway, but take it with a grain of salt!)

Let OC2O_{C_2}OC2​​ be the orbit category for the group of order 2 C2C_2C2​. So $$O_{C_2}$ has two objects: a strict terminal object denoted C2/C2C_2 / C_2C2​/C2​, and an object denoted C2C_2C2​ which has an automorphism group C2C_2C2​ and no other endomorphisms. (That's a complete description of the category!)

There is a functor E‾1:OC2op→Opd\underline E_1 : O_{C_2}^{op} \to OpdE​1​:OC2​op​→Opd (where OpdOpdOpd is the ∞\infty∞-category of operads) which carries C2//C2C_2 // C_2C2​//C2​ to the E0E_0E0​ operad (whose algebras are pointed objects) and carries C2C_2C2​ to the E1E_1E1​ operad (whose algebras are monoid objects). The C2C_2C2​ action on E1E_1E1​ is given by reversing the order of multiplication, and the map E0→E1E_0 \to E_1E0​→E1​ is the natural inclusion (on algebras, this induces the functor from monoid objects to pointed objects which forgets the multiplication and just remembers the unit).

The colimit (in OpdOpdOpd) of the functor E‾1\underline E_1E​1​ will be an operad which (E1)C2(E_1)_{C_2}(E1​)C2​​. An algebra for (E1)C2(E_1)_{C_2}(E1​)C2​​ is a monoid object AAA equipped with an equivalence of monoid objects A≅ArevA \cong A^{rev}A≅Arev which is the identity on the underlying object ∣A∣|A|∣A∣, along with some higher coherence conditions on this equivalence, and conditions saying that the higher coherence conditions are all trivial on the unit of AAA.

I might claim (???) that the algebras for the operad (E1)hC2(E_1)_{hC_2}(E1​)hC2​​ should be the "right" notion of "semibraided monoidal category". From what I've described, then, it's clear that a semibraided monoidal category should be a monoidal category CCC equipped with a monoidal equivalence ϕ:C≃Crev\phi: C \simeq C^{rev}ϕ:C≃Crev which restricts to the identity on the underlying category CCC, and such that the unit constraint of ϕ\phiϕ is the identity automorphism of the unit III of the monoidal category CCC -- plus some higher coherence.

Anyway, one of your questions was whether there were other compatibility conditions you "should" be imposing. I'm still not sure of the answer, but the above approach would give a way of formalizing your question.

For what it's worth, in our paper on distributive laws for lax functors we note that braidings can viewed as invertible distributive laws between the identity functors on a monoidal category (viewed as a 1-object bicategory).
From that perspective it would be natural to add some axioms that relate the semibraiding to the unitors when one of the objects is the unit of the monoidal category. I think it then follows from our results that semibraidings correspond to certain unitary lax monoidal structures on tensor product functor.
